newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - OCT 21.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK FINANCIAL NEWS - OCT 21.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek financial press:

--Prime Minister Costas Simitis gives his approval for harsh measures. A flurry of meetings today and tomorrow as the government's economic team puts together a budget walks the line between meeting the demands of the convergence programme and not betraying pre-election promises to impose new taxes.
--The 1996 budget out by 360 billion drachmas while the wage and interest bills exceed projected targets.
--The 'black hole' of spending on the unemployed creates a direct threat to the social security system. The bill: 750 billion drachmas.
--Athens luxury hotels see a 10.5 percent rise in overnight stays for the January-August 1996 period and forecast revenues of 35 billion drachmas by the end of the year.
--The government targets welfare benefits as it finds itself face-to-face with its 'social profile' in the need to draft a credible budget, faithful to the demands of convergence.

--What will change in the Greek banking system after 1997. Commercial and central bank officials foresee openings to new markets and free movement of capital, mergers, and the inevitable privatisation of more state-run banks.
--Government puts possibility of voluntary delay of taking retirement up for negotiation in talks due to begin next year on creating a viable social security system.

--Telecommunications organisation (OTE), National, Alpha Credit and Ergo Banks, Biohalko and Delta among the 12 listed companies presenting their wares to institutional investors in Boston and New York this week.

--The middle classes will bear the brunt of the tax burden again this year as expected changes to tax scales and exemptions are considered to be too weak to force the 'haves' to pay and the special tax crimes squad is still being put together.
--The merger of two of Greece's largest commercial banks -Alpha Credit and Ergo Bank - is still an option despite official denials.
--New tax bill before Parliament provides a month's grace for those who have not submitted tax declarations or need to make amendments and additions.

--Despite complaints from business circles that the 'hard drachma' policy is making life difficult for exporters, exports in the January-September 1996 period saw an impressive rise, up 19.6 percent overall and up 23.3 percent to European Union countries.
